title: European Union nations join ASAT testing ban
summary: Ahead of a final meeting of a United Nations working group on reducing space threats, members states of the European Union, but not the E.U. itself, have pledged not to conduct destructive direct-ascent anti-satellite tests.

title: RocketLab Flys Recovered Electron Engine For First Time
summary: Rocket Lab has achieved a significant milestone in the effort to make Electron reusable, for the first time the company has flown an engine that had previously flown before and was recovered from the ocean.

title: Space Force to seek industry ideas for rapid deployment of satellites
summary: The U.S. Space Force is kicking off a new initiative focused on the rapid deployment of satellites during conflicts or emergencies.

title: Viasat reports second satellite malfunction in a matter of weeks
summary: A second Viasat communications satellite is malfunctioning in orbit, this time from the fleet of recently acquired U.K.-based Inmarsat, the company said on Thursday.

title: North Korea Fails To Launch Spy Satellite Again
summary: North Korea has attempted to to launch a spy satellite again, but the mission ended in failure due to a critical "error in the emergency blasting system" during the third-stage flight, according to a statement from the nation's state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA).

title: Justice Department sues SpaceX over hiring practices
summary: The U.S. Justice Department has filed suit against SpaceX, alleging the company discriminated against asylum seekers and refugees in hiring.

title: SpaceX rolls Booster 9 back to the Launch Pad for more testing
summary: Following a short stay at the production site, Booster 9 has made its way back to the Orbital Launch Mount for additional...

title: NASA gives Crew-7 the “go” for launch to ISS on Friday
summary: NASA is preparing to launch its next astronaut rotation, Crew-7, to the International Space Station (ISS) this week on Friday, Aug. 25. The four astronauts will launch from Launch Complex 39A (LC-39A) at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida atop a SpaceX Falcon 9 Block 5 rocket in the Dragon spacecraft C210-3 Endurance, targeting liftoff at 3:49 AM EDT (07:49 UTC). NASA held a flight readiness review (FRR) on Monday, Aug. 21, and gave the official “go” for launch, after the spacecraft rolled out to the pad at LC-39A.

title: Rogers Bears Down on USSPACECOM Decision
summary: Rep. Mike Rogers (R-AL) is taking more steps to challenge President Biden’s decision to keep U.S. Space Command headquarters in Colorado instead of moving it to Alabama as promised by […]

title: NASA, Forest Service to Share Moon Tree Seedlings, Promote STEM
summary: Education and community organizations can apply to receive a living piece of spaceflight history to promote science, technology, engineering, and mathematics: a seedling grown from a tree seed that flew around the Moon on the NASA’s Artemis I mission in late 2022.
